trans-unit.source: Configure software RAID on avirtual machine running Linux in Azure
trans-unit.target: Configure software RAID on avirtual machine running Linux in Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use mdadm to configure RAID on Linux in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use mdadm to configure RAID on Linux in Azure.

trans-unit.source: It's a common scenario to use software RAID on Linux virtual machines in Azure to present multiple attached data disks as a single RAID device.
trans-unit.target: It's a common scenario to use software RAID on Linux virtual machines in Azure to present multiple attached data disks as a single RAID device.

trans-unit.source: Typically this can be used to improve performance and allow for improved throughput compared to using just a single disk.
trans-unit.target: Typically this can be used to improve performance and allow for improved throughput compared to using just a single disk.

trans-unit.source: Two or more empty data disks will typically be needed to configure a RAID device.
trans-unit.target: Two or more empty data disks will typically be needed to configure a RAID device.

trans-unit.source: This article will not go into detail on how to attach data disks to a Linux virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: This article will not go into detail on how to attach data disks to a Linux virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Please see the Microsoft Azure article <linkText>attach a disk</linkText><title></title> for detailed instructions on how to attach an empty data disk to a Linux virtual machine on Azure.
trans-unit.target: Please see the Microsoft Azure article <linkText>attach a disk</linkText><title></title> for detailed instructions on how to attach an empty data disk to a Linux virtual machine on Azure.

trans-unit.source: The ExtraSmall VM size does not support more than one data disk attached to the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: The ExtraSmall VM size does not support more than one data disk attached to the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Please see <linkText>Virtual Machine and Cloud Service Sizes for Microsoft Azure</linkText><title></title> for detailed information about VM sizes and the number of data disks supported.
trans-unit.target: Please see <linkText>Virtual Machine and Cloud Service Sizes for Microsoft Azure</linkText><title></title> for detailed information about VM sizes and the number of data disks supported.

trans-unit.source: Ubuntu
trans-unit.target: Ubuntu

trans-unit.source: CentOS & Oracle Linux
trans-unit.target: CentOS & Oracle Linux

trans-unit.source: SLES and openSUSE
trans-unit.target: SLES and openSUSE

trans-unit.source: In this example we will create a single disk partition on /dev/sdc.
trans-unit.target: In this example we will create a single disk partition on /dev/sdc.

trans-unit.source: The new disk partition will then be called /dev/sdc1.
trans-unit.target: The new disk partition will then be called /dev/sdc1.

trans-unit.source: Start fdisk to begin creating partitions
trans-unit.target: Start fdisk to begin creating partitions

trans-unit.source: Press 'n' at the prompt to create a new partition:
trans-unit.target: Press 'n' at the prompt to create a new partition:

trans-unit.source: Next, press 'p' to create a primary partition:
trans-unit.target: Next, press 'p' to create a primary partition:

trans-unit.source: Press '1' to select partition number 1:
trans-unit.target: Press '1' to select partition number 1:

trans-unit.source: Select the starting point of the new partition, or just press to accept the default to place the partition at the beginning of the free space on the drive:
trans-unit.target: Select the starting point of the new partition, or just press to accept the default to place the partition at the beginning of the free space on the drive:

trans-unit.source: Select the size of the partition, for example type '+10G' to create a 10 gigabyte partition. Or, just press create a single partition that spans the entire drive:
trans-unit.target: Select the size of the partition, for example type '+10G' to create a 10 gigabyte partition. Or, just press create a single partition that spans the entire drive:

trans-unit.source: Next, change the ID and type of the partition from the default ID '83' (Linux) to ID 'fd' (Linux raid auto):
trans-unit.target: Next, change the ID and type of the partition from the default ID '83' (Linux) to ID 'fd' (Linux raid auto):

trans-unit.source: Finally, write the partition table to the drive and exit fdisk:
trans-unit.target: Finally, write the partition table to the drive and exit fdisk:

trans-unit.source: The following example will "stripe" (RAID level 0) three partitions located on three separate data disks (sdc1, sdd1, sde1):
trans-unit.target: The following example will "stripe" (RAID level 0) three partitions located on three separate data disks (sdc1, sdd1, sde1):

trans-unit.source: In this example, after running this command a new RAID device called /dev/md127 will be created.
trans-unit.target: In this example, after running this command a new RAID device called /dev/md127 will be created.

trans-unit.source: Also note that if these data disks we previously part of another defunct RAID array it may be necessary to add the --force parameter to the mdadm command.
trans-unit.target: Also note that if these data disks we previously part of another defunct RAID array it may be necessary to add the --force parameter to the mdadm command.

trans-unit.source: Create the file system on the new RAID device
trans-unit.target: Create the file system on the new RAID device

trans-unit.source: CentOS, Oracle Linux, SLES 12, openSUSE and Ubuntu
trans-unit.target: CentOS, Oracle Linux, SLES 12, openSUSE and Ubuntu

trans-unit.source: SLES 11
trans-unit.target: SLES 11

trans-unit.source: SLES 11 & openSUSE - enable boot.md and create mdadm.conf
trans-unit.target: SLES 11 & openSUSE - enable boot.md and create mdadm.conf

trans-unit.source: A reboot may be required after making these changes on SUSE systems.
trans-unit.target: A reboot may be required after making these changes on SUSE systems.

trans-unit.source: This step is not required on SLES 12.
trans-unit.target: This step is not required on SLES 12.

trans-unit.source: Caution: Improperly editing the /etc/fstab file could result in an unbootable system.
trans-unit.target: Caution: Improperly editing the /etc/fstab file could result in an unbootable system.

trans-unit.source: If unsure, please refer to the distribution's documentation for information on how to properly edit this file.
trans-unit.target: If unsure, please refer to the distribution's documentation for information on how to properly edit this file.

trans-unit.source: It is also recommended that a backup of the /etc/fstab file is created before editing.
trans-unit.target: It is also recommended that a backup of the /etc/fstab file is created before editing.

trans-unit.source: Create the desired mount point for your new file system, for example:
trans-unit.target: Create the desired mount point for your new file system, for example:

trans-unit.source: When editing /etc/fstab, the UUID should be used to reference the file system rather than the device name.
trans-unit.target: When editing /etc/fstab, the UUID should be used to reference the file system rather than the device name.

trans-unit.source: Use the blkid utility to determine the UUID for the new file system:
trans-unit.target: Use the blkid utility to determine the UUID for the new file system:

trans-unit.source: Open /etc/fstab in a text editor and add an entry for the new file system, for example:
trans-unit.target: Open /etc/fstab in a text editor and add an entry for the new file system, for example:

trans-unit.source: Or on SLES 11 & openSUSE:
trans-unit.target: Or on SLES 11 & openSUSE:

trans-unit.source: Then, save and close /etc/fstab.
trans-unit.target: Then, save and close /etc/fstab.

trans-unit.source: Test that the /etc/fstab entry is correct:
trans-unit.target: Test that the /etc/fstab entry is correct:

trans-unit.source: If this command results in an error message please check the syntax in the /etc/fstab file.
trans-unit.target: If this command results in an error message please check the syntax in the /etc/fstab file.

trans-unit.source: Next run the mount command to ensure the file system is mounted:
trans-unit.target: Next run the mount command to ensure the file system is mounted:

trans-unit.source: (Optional) Failsafe Boot Parameters
trans-unit.target: (Optional) Failsafe Boot Parameters

trans-unit.source: fstab configuration
trans-unit.target: fstab configuration

trans-unit.source: Many distributions include either the nobootwait or nofail mount parameters that may be added to the /etc/fstab file.
trans-unit.target: Many distributions include either the nobootwait or nofail mount parameters that may be added to the /etc/fstab file.

trans-unit.source: These parameters allow for failures when mounting a particular file system and allow the Linux system to continue to boot even if it is unable to properly mount the RAID file system.
trans-unit.target: These parameters allow for failures when mounting a particular file system and allow the Linux system to continue to boot even if it is unable to properly mount the RAID file system.

trans-unit.source: Please refer to your distribution's documentation for more information on these parameters.
trans-unit.target: Please refer to your distribution's documentation for more information on these parameters.

trans-unit.source: Example (Ubuntu):
trans-unit.target: Example (Ubuntu):

trans-unit.source: Linux boot parameters
trans-unit.target: Linux boot parameters

trans-unit.source: In addition to the above parameters, the kernel parameter "bootdegraded=true" can allow the system to boot even if the RAID is perceived as damaged or degraded, for example if a data drive is inadvertently removed from the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: In addition to the above parameters, the kernel parameter "bootdegraded=true" can allow the system to boot even if the RAID is perceived as damaged or degraded, for example if a data drive is inadvertently removed from the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: By default this could also result in a non-bootable system.
trans-unit.target: By default this could also result in a non-bootable system.

trans-unit.source: Please refer to your distribution's documentation on how to properly edit kernel parameters.
trans-unit.target: Please refer to your distribution's documentation on how to properly edit kernel parameters.

trans-unit.source: For example, in many distributions (CentOS, Oracle Linux, SLES 11) these parameters may be added manually to the "/boot/grub/menu.lst" file.
trans-unit.target: For example, in many distributions (CentOS, Oracle Linux, SLES 11) these parameters may be added manually to the "/boot/grub/menu.lst" file.

trans-unit.source: On Ubuntu this parameter can be added to the GRUB_CMDLINE_LINUX_DEFAULT variable on "/etc/default/grub".
trans-unit.target: On Ubuntu this parameter can be added to the GRUB_CMDLINE_LINUX_DEFAULT variable on "/etc/default/grub".
